content.description: Crux at bolt 3 and 4 rounding over ledge coming off crimpy face to next head wall with high 5 bolt to prevent rope drag during slaby finish
content.location: Main wall left, starts on top of high left boulder left of cougar arete

content.description: Climb starts on the pedestal of a giant chock stone just at the second tier of the gully.
content.location: Follow against the wall to the left until it cuts up into a gully

climbs.name: White Streak
climbs.fa: Unknown, bolted Dec.2018 to existing anchors

content.description: Little harder at start but all there for a 5.8

climbs.name: What Day Is It? (aka Sweet Child of Mine)

content.description: What Day Is It? I say 5.11c. It is just across from the white wall. Approach up into the gully and start the climb on the middle boulder face, climb up into the overhang make a clip, then you're in it! Go up to a jug haul finish.
content.protection:
Four bolts, bolt anchor.

The first bolt is missing.
content.location: Far left side of the crag up in a cove. It's a rap off or walk off.

content.description:
Start matched on a good jug at about face height. Get an okay high right foot, and throw up left for a  bad crimp. Get an okay left foot and reach up and hit a poor side pull with your right hand. Bring both feet up on the starting jug and its an easy top out to the immediate right (there will be a bush in your face though), or a committing top out all the way up (Both are fairly easy)

It can be pretty easily bouldered, but there are bolts on top for a TR set up.

Just though it was such a fun problem that it deserved to get put up on MP. If any one has any further info on it please let me know!
content.protection: Boulder pad, or anchor bolts for a TR.
content.location: Just to the right of Stranger Danger. It's an independent boulder just to the right of the main cougar face.
West facing wall right of Insecurity Never Wins

content.description: The crux is right off of the ground. Its a high reach to a crimp and slopper up to a good edge, get your feet up and make a clip.. A few more crux moves and the climbing gets easier as you go up.
content.location: just left of Bloody Monday. facing the main wall.

content.description: Start at the bottom of the central face pull up on to the face and follow edges up to a nice red point crux. careful after rains this face gets covered with sand and dirt.
content.location: the middle wall high up on the trail.

content.description:
Up the face to the roof then traverse right feeling the exposure finish up the corner.

Two bolt anchor set 3 feet back at top will require extending to minimize rope drag.

Walk off decent to climbers right may be easier than cleaning via rappel

Enchains the cruxes of both Stranger Danger and Social Distancing. Climb Stranger Danger for most of the route and then cut right for the fun bolted roof of Social Distancing. The lower slab dries out quicker after a rainstorm then Social Distancing.
Low boulder like moves off the ground well protected to slab finish

climbs.name: Screw That, Tell Her to Eat Ramen Alone

content.description: Not sure the history, but this is the most obvious line on the rock.  Probably top roped a bunch of times, but reasonable to lead on gear. Happy to update if anyone has more info about it, just picked a silly name for it. Follows a crack in between Three Musketeers and Butter Fingers and finishes up at the top of Butter Fingers. A couple fun finger locks and slab moves down low leads to an easier top.
content.protection: Small offset nuts (DMM Peenut size) and cams in the BD 0.2.-0.3 range. Bolt anchors.
content.location: Between Three Musketeers and Butter Fingers.

content.description:
5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with quick links. Entire route is bolted with 1/2” powers stainless steel bolts and stainless hardware torqued with a torque wrench for accuracy. I attempted to make the bolt spacing logical and well protected. Bolts protect more commiting moves and are within reach at good clipping stances.

Crux is going above second bolt. Good route for a new leader but maybe not a first lead.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor using 1/2” Powers stainless bolts with Fixe stainless hangers
content.location: On the approach to the main crag, youll come through a little tunnel of trees and scrub brush. Once you exit that tunnel you will find yourself at a slabby base. The furthest right bolt line just left of the ridge is Santiago.

content.description: The obvious flaring crack that starts in the cave.
content.protection: standard rack one bolt on crux.
content.location: start the route in the crack at the corner of the cave.

content.description: The route starts with thin feet, but good pockety hand holds and goes into a tight fingers crack as the rock angle lets up. After clipping the crux bolt you pull the thin bouldery crux. The climb finishes with an exciting mantle over a sloping rail.
content.protection:
#6 and #10 BD nuts

2 Small BD C3 Cams

4 Bolts

Shared Bolt Anchor
content.location: The crack to the left of Insecurity Never Wins.

content.description: Moderate slab climbing leads to a crack. This is the first crux. The next section of climbing has one big crux move on steep rock with big holds to a juggy top-out.
content.protection: 10 bolts to shared anchors with "what day is it"
content.location: Walk up the trail and follow the top of the cliff line to the west. Here a new trail descends to a hidden wall.

content.description:
Toprope right leaning crack next to Shelter in place sharing same anchor.

Possible trad lead with sketchy small nut placements.

Climb up the arête of the slab that is near the entrance to the crag.

"Enter Slabman" on left "Santiago" on right.

No visual of climber at anchor and loud highway noises make these routes difficult to belay.

Shout loud and clear calls for safety!
content.protection: 3 bolts + Anchor. Quick links on Anchor. Runout and adventurous!

content.description: Just to the left of Stranger Danger, climb up the arete.
content.protection:
This route has been re-bolted recently.  It is now well protected with new bolts and chains.  Thanks to whoever!

"route has 9 bolts and chain anchors set Aug. 2018" Joshua Horn
content.location: start at the arete on the middle face of the crag.

content.description: Slab climb, low crux to second bolt then eases way up.
Start left of the boulder climb up to the first bolt make a reach for the clip and pull through the crux the rest is easy low angle until the last 8ft, it more vertical up to shuts for the anchor.
content.location: its on the free standing rock near the main wall on the trail.

content.description: This is the best boulder on the hillside. It starts on a rail with good holds and ends slightly right. There are several variations. The original route went straight up and was V4. A hold broke making for a slightly different finish and bringing the grade down a bit. Overall a beautiful, steep boulder problem on positive holds!
content.protection: One pad and a spotter. Flat landing.
content.location: Just below and left of the Cougar Face.

content.description: A fun climb on good holds up high to an old bolt with option for not so great pro up to the bolt, runout after the bolt to the top. crux is at the bolt.
content.location: Start this climb in the corner of the face just right of the cave.
